As you can see thre is a call to:
Nop.Core.Caching.PerRequestCacheManager.Get
which grabs a reader lock. We have a cache miss so we call into the aquire() Func which calls into the settings service which results in a get into Redis Cache and again into the PerRequest cache and again tries to enter as a reader again (recursion).
Looking at my original Pull again I think the best, and most correct, fix is to update the PerRequstCache Get method and use only a Reader lock when necessary and if a cache miss occurs ensure we are not acquiring the value with a held lock. Finally I can then grab a writer lock if the acquisition works.

. I was going to bring up something on the 3.4 roadmap, but because it was already looking awesome, I was going to wait until 3.5 before bringing this up. But seeing the statement "make it configurable because it can seriosly affect performance (disable by default) ", I will mention it now.
If we took a different architecture approach, many of these expensive lookups could be minimized. If we had an additional background job that ran off a queue, we could do very complex logic like this work item is requesting with no performance impact.
Just like cache is updated when we save a product in the admin, any changes could also be pushed to a stack (similar to what we are doing already with activity monitor). So, lets look at a practical scenario.
Store admin comes in and makes price adjustments to attribute options and maybe even updates a lot of attribute combinations. We write (using a queue paradigm) the events to a background work stack. So, an example row would be (ProductId, enum for price adjustment, etc). Within a min or two, the background job would pull off the stack and determine (From and To) prices based on changes, then write these 2 values right into 2 new columns in the product table and updates the cache as normal.
When this product is pulled for the Catalog for someone browsing, the From and To are now simple fields that have no "real-time" calculation needed.
This same architecture shift could be applied to many many scenarios in nopCommerce. The goal being, during user browsing of the site, avoid complex logic by just putting results as simple attributes, and leaving the calculation of those values to back-end services. 
As this work item is on the 3.4 roadmap now, I will make a note in the roadmap thread.
. One additional point to the above comment. Essentially this adds up to introducing the concept of "Calculated fields" populated by background jobs to make catalog browsing faster.

. After some discussion decided not to implement it out of the box. It can affect performance too much. Leave it for customization. The creation of a Reseller (or "Partner") Portal where resellers can register customers and order on a customers behalf.
The portal should allow the Partner to see only customers associated with them and orders only they have processed. A Partner Resources section where they can get logos, product descriptions etc would be helpful. Resellers are most useful for overseas and often foreign language sales.
Resellers purchase products at a discount and have the ability to turn off customer notifications about registration and also the option to hide order information (i.e,. the price paid) from the customer. Resellers whom separately bill the customer can then order products under their own pricing arrangements and can arrange for direct delivery either to the reseller or the customer.
In the case of downloadable products, the customer can login and download the product, but the reseller can't access the customer download, unless permitted by the store owner.
Ideally Partners would be organised in separate classes with different administration rights depending on classes. eg. A "Distributor" might have the ability to refund orders, a basic reseller may not.
This can actually be done using a mashup of the Administration Interface combined the "Affiliate" functionality ("Partner" is a much better term). We have done this by hacking the code a bit which means it is not appropriate to share - it needs to be done properly.
The result was support for both "Affiliate" and "Reseller" management in one place. Both can login and seeeither how their Affiliate program membership is going or in the case of resellers can administer most features of the affiliated customers (affiliates only see customer name) .

. добавление колонки и reference в upgrade.sql не правильное. надо посмореть, как я делал раньше:
первое, ALTER TABLE [dbo].[Store] SET (LOCK_ESCALATION = TABLE) и ALTER TABLE [dbo].[ProductReview] SET (LOCK_ESCALATION = TABLE) - это лишнее
второе, добавлять CONSTRAINT DF_ProductReview_StoreId не надо. 
третье, имя CONSTRAINT (FK_ProductReview_Store) должно 100% быть таким, как если бы ты установил магазин с нуля (без апгрейда). попробуй локально установить магазин и посмотри, как будет называться CONSTRAINT (reference).
четвертое, UPDATE [dbo].[ProductReview] SET StoreId = @DefaultStoreId WHERE 1=1
выглядит как костыли. надо просто установить StoreId у него, у кого оно сейчас null -
UPDATE [dbo].[ProductReview] SET StoreId = @DefaultStoreId WHERE StoreId is null
пятое, любой upgrade.sql скрипт должен иметь воззможность быть выполненным (запущенным) несколько раз (пока мы разрабатывает nopCommerce, то выполняем его по сто раз до выхода версии). в твоем случае это не сработает, так как такие constrant и поля уже будут существовать

. /// <summary>
    /// Save settings object (per store). If the setting is not overridden per storem then it'll be delete
    /// </summary>
    /// <typeparam name="T">Entity type</typeparam>
    /// <typeparam name="TPropType">Property type</typeparam>
    /// <param name="settings">Settings</param>
    /// <param name="keySelector">Key selector</param>
    /// <param name="overrideForStore">A value indicating whether to setting is overridden in some store</param>
    /// <param name="storeId">Store ID</param>
    /// <param name="clearCache">A value indicating whether to clear cache after setting update</param>
    public virtual void SaveSettingOverridablePerStore<T, TPropType>(T settings,
        Expression<Func<T, TPropType>> keySelector,
        bool overrideForStore, int storeId = 0, bool clearCache = true) where T : ISettings, new()
    {
        if (overrideForStore || storeId == 0)
            SaveSetting(settings, keySelector, storeId, clearCache);
        else if (storeId > 0)
            DeleteSetting(settings, keySelector, storeId);
    }

4. предлагаю реализовать также эту задачу Add async support for events. сделать вызовы и обработку событий асинхронными.

Как я понял, основная задача - разгрузить сервер, чтобы при запросе сторонних сервисов (платежки, доставка и прочее) thread сразу возвращался обратно в thread pool, не дожидаясь окончания выполнения запроса к API, так как размер thread pool ограничен, и при большой загруженности и долгих ответах от сторонних сервисов сервер перестанет справляться.
При изучении этой темы я наткнулся на следующие моменты - для того, чтобы сделать действительно асинхронное выполнение действий внутри запроса, при которых thread не будет занят и будет сразу возвращаться (чего мы и хотим) сделать асинхронными только контроллеры, как предлагается в исходной задаче будет недостаточным. Нам нужно будет проваливаться с написанием асинхронного кода глубже и глубже вплоть до кода плагинов, и уже там требовать асинхронных вызовов API, то есть сторонние библиотеки должны предлагать такие методы, либо разработчики плагинов сами должны писать асинхронную обработку запросов к API сервисов. Только в таком случае выполнение кода будет действительно асинхронным.
Другой подход заключается в том, чтобы использовать асинхронные обертки над синхронными методами, тогда будет достаточно обернуть вызовы сторонних сервисов внутри контроллеров. Но такой подход не даст требуемого результата - исходный thread запроса будет возвращаться, но при этом, для обрабоки действий внутри обертки, будет взят другой из thread pool. Единственное, что конечный пользователь сможет совершать другие действия в то время, пока дожидается ответа от сервисов, но выигрыша по количеству свободных thread это не даст.
таким образом, можно:
переписать большинство методов с учетом поддержки асинхронного кода и заставить всех разработчиков плагинов также поддерживать асинхронный код (действительно с применением асинхронных методов обработки вызовов API, либо писать обертки поверх обычного кода)
сделать в контроллерах асинхронные обертки поверх существующего кода в тех местах, где вызываются сервисы.
оставить, как есть, без поддержки асинхронности

Как я понял, основная задача - разгрузить сервер, чтобы при запросе сторонних сервисов (платежки, доставка и прочее) thread сразу возвращался обратно в thread pool, не дожидаясь окончания выполнения запроса к API, так как размер thread pool ограничен, и при большой загруженности и долгих ответах от сторонних сервисов сервер перестанет справляться.
При изучении этой темы я наткнулся на следующие моменты - для того, чтобы сделать действительно асинхронное выполнение действий внутри запроса, при которых thread не будет занят и будет сразу возвращаться (чего мы и хотим) сделать асинхронными только контроллеры, как предлагается в исходной задаче будет недостаточным. Нам нужно будет проваливаться с написанием асинхронного кода глубже и глубже вплоть до кода плагинов, и уже там требовать асинхронных вызовов API, то есть сторонние библиотеки должны предлагать такие методы, либо разработчики плагинов сами должны писать асинхронную обработку запросов к API сервисов. Только в таком случае выполнение кода будет действительно асинхронным.
Другой подход заключается в том, чтобы использовать асинхронные обертки над синхронными методами, тогда будет достаточно обернуть вызовы сторонних сервисов внутри контроллеров. Но такой подход не даст требуемого результата - исходный thread запроса будет возвращаться, но при этом, для обрабоки действий внутри обертки, будет взят другой из thread pool. Единственное, что конечный пользователь сможет совершать другие действия в то время, пока дожидается ответа от сервисов, но выигрыша по количеству свободных thread это не даст.
таким образом, можно:
1. переписать большинство методов с учетом поддержки асинхронного кода и заставить всех разработчиков плагинов также поддерживать асинхронный код (действительно с применением асинхронных методов обработки вызовов API, либо писать обертки поверх обычного кода)
2. сделать в контроллерах асинхронные обертки поверх существующего кода в тех местах, где вызываются сервисы.
3. оставить, как есть, без поддержки асинхронности
4. назначить задачу на кого-то еще и дать поразбираться, не уверен, что я все понял правильно

suddenelfilio:
Nop-templates Web Api plugin looks ok, but I attended the devdays this year and spotted various culprits in their implementation:
- Specifiying fields to be returned without transparantly querying them down to the database is no advantage => you still query all the data, but only at json serialization you filter out the data specified in fields... For what? better bandwidth? Bandwidth is cheap you should focus on server resources. 
- The partial updates using Delta are breaking convention. On one hand you can update only the fields you specify in a PUT, but on the other hand you delete all not mentioned items in a collection/relation? That's not consistent with the expectation of Partial updates.
- Returning images as BASE64 is effectivly killing off any CDN browser/proxy/server caching you might use as you are still returning a bunch of string data. It would be better to provide the url to image and let the framework used figure out how to render it. Or at least provide a way to select the behavior.
- Also no fan of snake casing as it does not add any value to the REST principle. If you want to access items from an order your should use api/order//items and not api/order//order_items => why specify order_items when the parent entity you are querying though is already an Order. Logic provides that the items will be order items. It is the same as saying I have an Order class with properties like OrderId, OrderDate, OrderItems and so on... No those properties should be Id, Date, Items  really no need for repeating/prefixen the "Order".
  -Not sure about this one, but I really hope that things like sorting/filtering/paging are done on the datasets in memory (like the fields "feature") because again you just lose any performance gain your might get by propagating this down to the data query itself.
Okay gonna stop rambling on now... sorry for that, but I'm an REST API purist when comes to stuff like this.
Another note I believe you might benefit more from introducing something like Web Hooks instead of exposing the API.

. Closed #774. I was able to solve the problem (a general solution using refactoring). But faced with other constraint in SQL CE when using with "IsMaxLength" extension method: 
field type ntext cannot be used in WHERE, HAVING, GROUP BY, ON, or IN clauses. This makes it impossible to use NTEXT to overcome the limitation of 4000 characters for string fields.
But I will post here my solution, maybe in the future it will work.
First I added public function to NopEntityTypeConfiguration class:
```
/// 
/// Configures all string properies (in addition to those fields for which clearly defined maximum length)
/// to allow the maximum length supported by the database provider
/// 
public virtual void SetStringMaxLength()
{
    //get ignorable properties
    var filterConf = this.GetType().GetProperty("Configuration", BindingFlags.NonPublic | BindingFlags.Instance).GetValue(this);
    var filter = filterConf.GetType().GetProperty("IgnoredProperties", BindingFlags.NonPublic | BindingFlags.Instance).GetValue(filterConf) as IEnumerable;
    var ignoredProperties = filter != null ? filter.Select(p => p.Name).ToList() : new List();
var names = typeof(T).GetProperties()
    .Where(p => p.PropertyType == typeof(string))
    .Where(p=>!ignoredProperties.Contains(p.Name))
    .Select(p => p.Name).ToArray();

var expression = names.Select(name => Core.DynamicExpression.ParseLambda<T, string>(name, null));

foreach (var expr in expression)
{
    var prop = this.Property(expr);
    var temp = prop
        .GetType()
        .GetProperties(BindingFlags.NonPublic | BindingFlags.Instance).FirstOrDefault(p => p.Name == "Configuration");

    if (temp == null)
        continue;

    var obj = temp.GetValue(prop);
    var maxLength = obj.GetType().GetRuntimeProperty("MaxLength").GetValue(obj);

    if (maxLength == null)
        //uses ntext in sqlcompact, NVARCHAR(MAX) in SQL Server
        Property(expr).IsMaxLength();
}

}
```
Then I added code to NopObjectContext.OnModelCreating in line 46:
//use this approach to determine the Sql CE is not necessary, may have a better solution.
var dataProviderInstance = EngineContext.Current.Resolve<BaseDataProviderManager>().LoadDataProvider() as SqlCeDataProvider;
if (dataProviderInstance != null)
    configurationInstance.SetStringMaxLength();

If you change CustomerSettings.HashedPasswordFormat on an existing site from SHA1 to SHA256, If I read the code correctly, login attempts would compare passwords with different hash types, effectively breaking the site.
An indicator on the Customer entity of which hash format is used probably wouldn't hurt security.  A determined attacker will likely be able to determine the hash type used by inspecting the number of characters that the hash is anyway.
As an added bonus, if a customer with an older hash format logs into a system currently using a newer hash format, we can write the new value and thus the customer base will progressively migrate to a more secure format.

. I think filesystem is preferred for logs instead of RDBMS.
For example Web Servers like IIS, Apache, etc save their access and error logs in files instead of RDBMS by default.
Maybe people asks How to log filesystem error if it fails?
And it is quite true, but if that fails, there is more chances that your DB is inaccessible as well.
For putting it all together:
1. Too many things can fail with the database, and logging this failures is important too.
2. Also there is an extra layer between our application and the DB (ORM like EntityFramework) that it has its probability and chances of error and failure.
3. Unless you have a database system allowing autonomous transactions (or no transactions at all), logging would require a separate connection so a rollback or commit in logging doesn’t interfere with rollback or commit in the application.
4. Many things worth logging happen during startup, i.e. possibly before the database connection has been established.
I believe using logging frameworks like Log4net or NLog is more safe solution for logging.

This controller adds a route that will enable the let's encrypt to access the challenge file through the web
be defining the route:
[Route( ".well-known/acme-challenge/{id}" )].
Now, in NopCommerce, if the route attributes are not supported, this would need to be mapped somewhere, where the routes are defined.
The full path to the file Let's Encrypt creates will be:
/.well-known/acme-challenge/
The file names are cryptic like: aksdf83klsdfnsfdo2390fsadlmf, just FYI.

1. To manage the memory caching by single point and be able to make changes at root level if required. Also it manage the clearing cache keys by pattern and abstract the usage to simplify that.
2. _allKeys dic is responsible for the deleting cache object by regex pattern somthing like starts with given key.. > Based on a preliminary analysis I see the following problems.

When there are many items in the cache RegisterPostEvictionCallback calls back the PostEviction method very frequently. Consider 100000 items, all expiring in 1 hour, and they creation are evenly distributed within an hour. Then every 3600 sec / 100000=0.036 second you got a callback in this method. This is 27 call per second. The real situation is much worse, because the cache additions are not evenly distributed at all in time.
What does PostEviction do? It calls ClearKeys, which iterates thru _allKeys using a linear search (Where). For 100000 items this needs considerable time and CPU. This is the reason a production server is experiencing slowdown during a day. I used procdump to create a memory dump when the CPU for the worker process is more than 90% for 30 seconds. What did I see in the dump? 14 of the 30 threads were executing ClearKeys! Because it is a tight CPU loop, it sucks all CPUs to the ground.
Why do you call ClearKeys for when an item is removed from the cache? Why bother checking other items during the callback of a particular item? Why not call ClearKeys on a timer thread for every 10 seconds or so?
The next one, this actually also causes serious CPU burning is the IsCrawler method. It creates 5000 regex object for each call, and evaluates all of them if the user agent string is not a search engine. If you simply create and store the Regex object instead of string during the initialization the performance doubles at least. If you concat the pieces by (regex1)|(regex2), etc. manner to create one, big regex, the performance becomes even better.
Why I mention this method too? After a day of profiling I can claim that 75% of the CPU is eaten by ClearKeys and IsCrawler!!!
One other problem which does not bother me at this moment because I don't see it in the profiler and the memory dumps, but can cause pain in the back later: RemoveByPattern.
This is problematic, the code creates a compiled regex for each call! Compiled regex without caching the regex objects?
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/513412/how-does-regexoptions-compiled-work

Something like that:
var timer = new Timer(state => {ClearKeys();}, null, WAIT_TIME_TO_START, 10);. It will not burn your cpu if you have lower than ~1 million cache key. The issue not about calling the ClearKeys. For as there are some optimiziations that are nearly obsolete when using http/2 and Google PageSpeed does not recognize http/2 enabled websites.

So 20 tiny ressources are much faster loaded parallel than (for example) two big combined ressources (css, js, sprites).

If you call AutoMapperConfiguration.Init() in AutoMapperStartupTaskTest, then that will work fine in your AutoMapperConfigurationTest when run in isolation. However at runtime, the two AutoMapperStartup tasks will conflict, both calling Init() - the last IStartupTask to run will replace the MapperConfiguration and IMapper with its own registrations, causing runtime exceptions when you try to map anything from the other project. 
Instead, we need to ensure all configurations are applied before calling _mapperConfiguration.CreateMapper() in AutoMapperConfiguration.Init(), and also that the Mapper and  MapperConfiguration properties cannot be overwritten;
The other problem as it stands is that every project and plugin that uses AutoMapper would need to reference the Nop.Admin project, in order to reference the AutoMapperConfiguration class.

I got this issue to do, but a problem has arisen.
The method GetThisPageUrl() has two overloads:
GetThisPageUrl(bool includeQueryString)
GetThisPageUrl(bool includeQueryString, bool useSsl)
If we add a new bool parameter with default value, those who use the second method will switch to using the first method without knowing.
In nopCommerce solution, the second is used only in NopHttpsRequirementAttribute, and it's easy to change. But, in thirdy part plugins, this can be a silent problem.
Perhaps it is better to create a new method in WebHelper.
What do you think?. I agree, in this case we have no conflict.
But, following this line, another possibility would be to create the default parameter only in the method: GetThisPageUrl (bool includeQueryString, bool useSsl).
We would have the following scenario:
GetThisPageUrl (bool includeQueryString)
GetThisPageUrl (bool includeQueryString, bool useSsl, bool ignoreCase = true)
Both ways solve the problem. I did a pull request with this feature: https://github.com/nopSolutions/nopCommerce/pull/2380.

From what I understand, the ClearPluginAssemblies code runs after the Nop.Web project is built. If you have a plugin, it might not be built before Nop.Web is. The result is that the plugin output directories might or might not be cleared. If you have a project that depends on Nop.Web, it will always be built after Nop.Web, and thus the dlls might not be deleted.
If you take the system and Clean it, then build the solution, you will find that not all of the plugin directories are properly cleaned. If you build a second time they will be. You get similar results when you publish - if you don't do a couple of full solution builds before publishing, not all plugins will be properly built.. I'm not going to say I totally understand all of the stuff that's going on when the solution is built. I've read the csproj files, both for plugins and nop.web. From the comments, there is extra work being done in nop.web after the project is built.
That being said, I do know there are lots of weirdness going on during a build. Running a Clean doesn't always work - you have to run it multiple times. Similarly running a build all doesn't always work. Again you have to do this multiple times. Publish is another one like this. I suspect it's mostly a Visual Studio issue, but again I don't know. It really just comes down to it not working well.
Nop.Web is the target of everything - it's what is run. Logically, Nop.Web depends on all of the plugins to operate cleanly, but VS doesn't know/understand that. The models/factories shouldn't be in Nop.Web if you expect anyone to ever need access to them from a plugin. In fact, Nop.Web shouldn't have anything that will need to be used from a plugin. . From what I've been able to understand, there are security issues when you use compression over https. The default in the Microsoft code is to disable compression when https is used. However, this is a poor solution as some things (bundled css/js) have no sensitive information, and can be safely compressed. The issue relates to a BREACH attack, and would apply to pages showing sensitive information only. So, it sounds like what we need is a way of selectively enabling/disabling compression, on a per-page basis. It should be disabled for the back-end, and enabled for most public pages..

Hi, 
If you want your NuGet .dlls to be copied to plugin output, you need to make sure your .csproj looks like this:
```


netcoreapp2.1
true


....\Presentation\Nop.Web\Plugins\SamplePlugin\
$(OutputPath)


....\Presentation\Nop.Web\Plugins\SamplePlugin\
$(OutputPath)






false


false


false


false


false








```
Important parts are "CopyLocalLockFileAssemblies" set to true and "FilterCopyLocalItems" part, other than that everything is default for nopCommerce plugins.
If your library has many dependencies you need to specify them all, for instance here is what we did for Microsoft.AspNetCore.OData:
<Target Name="FilterCopyLocalItems" AfterTargets="ResolveLockFileCopyLocalProjectDeps">
    <ItemGroup>
      <ReferenceCopyLocalPaths Remove="@(ReferenceCopyLocalPaths)" Condition="'%(Filename)' != 'Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.JwtBearer' AND '%(Filename)' != 'Microsoft.AspNetCore.OData' AND '%(Filename)' != 'Microsoft.IdentityModel.Protocols.OpenIdConnect' AND '%(Filename)' != 'Microsoft.IdentityModel.Logging' AND '%(Filename)' != 'Microsoft.IdentityModel.Protocols' AND '%(Filename)' != 'Microsoft.IdentityModel.Tokens' AND '%(Filename)' != 'Microsoft.OData.Core' AND '%(Filename)' != 'Microsoft.OData.Edm' AND '%(Filename)' != 'System.IdentityModel.Tokens.Jwt' AND '%(Filename)' != 'Microsoft.Spatial'" />
    </ItemGroup>
  </Target>
Hope it helps,
John,
GrandNode Team

soci1248:
Can someone explain what is the rationale behind the MemoryCacheManager?
1. What is the exact responsibilities it wants to achieve?
2. Particularly, what is the purpose of the _allKeys dictionary? Why it is needed, why the underlying cache cannot supply this information?
I would be happy to optimize it and contribute it back, but first I have to understand exactly why did you introduce the _allKeys dictionary? For larger sites it kills all the cpus, this is a serious performance bug.. Based on a preliminary analysis I see the following problems. 
When there are many items in the cache RegisterPostEvictionCallback calls back the PostEviction method very frequently. Consider 100000 items, all expiring in 1 hour, and their creation are evenly distributed within an hour. Then every 3600 sec / 100000=0.036 second you got a callback in this method. This is 27 call per second. The real situation is much worse, because the cache additions are not evenly distributed at all in time.
What does PostEviction do? It calls ClearKeys, which iterates thru _allKeys using a linear search (Where). For 100000 items this needs considerable time and CPU. This is the reason a production server is experiencing slowdown during a day. I used procdump to create a memory dump when the CPU for the worker process is more than 90% for 30 seconds. What did I see in the dump? 14 of the 30 threads were executing ClearKeys! Because it is a tight CPU loop, it sucks all CPUs to the ground.
Why do you call ClearKeys for when an item is removed from the cache? Why bother checking other items during the callback of a particular item? Why not call ClearKeys on a timer thread for every 10 seconds or so?
The next one, this actually also causes serious CPU burning is the IsCrawler method. It creates 5000 regex object for each call, and evaluates all of them if the user agent string is not a search engine. If you simply create and store the Regex object instead of string during the initialization the performance doubles at least. If you concat the pieces by (regex1)|(regex2), etc. manner to create one, big regex, the performance becomes even better.
Why I mention this method too? After a day of profiling I can claim that 75% of the CPU is eaten by ClearKeys and IsCrawler!!!
One other problem which does not bother me at this moment because I don't see it in the profiler and the memory dumps, but can cause pain in the back later: RemoveByPattern. 
This is problematic, the code creates a compiled regex for each call! Compiled regex without caching the regex objects? 
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/513412/how-does-regexoptions-compiled-work. Good progress, thanks. One more very easy but dramatically efficient optimization could exploit the fact that there is a strong serial correlation between the bot requests. I.e. google starts to crawl a site it will do it for the next several minutes. When the BrowscapXmlHelper identified a bot using the slow regex approach it could cache the exact user agent string which come from the bot. So, for the subsequent request it could answer from this cache within nanoseconds.
A HashSet + lock might be appropriate for this task, or you could use ConcurrentDictionary with null Value.
If you afraid filling the memory with cached user agent strings you can use a sliding time expiration cache with 1-2 hours of duration.. What about the ClearKeys()?
